description: Expresses opposition or contrast, often highlighting something surprising or unexpected. More emphatic than simple 'mais'.
usage: Used to introduce information that contrasts with expectations based on what was previously stated. Can be placed at the beginning or in the middle of a sentence.

examples.french: Il n'a pas beaucoup étudié, pourtant il a réussi l'examen.
examples.english: He didn't study much, yet he passed the exam.

examples.french: Le film a de bonnes critiques, pourtant je ne l'ai pas aimé.
examples.english: The movie has good reviews, yet I didn't like it.
examples.context: Personal opinion contrasting with general opinion
Emphasizing that something should be obvious

notes: Emphasizes the contrast more than 'mais'. Often implies surprise at the contradiction.
